FacilityName: Southern Foods Group, LLC d/b/a Oak Farms Dairy
OperatorName: Southern Foods Group, LLC dba Oak F

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The stationary source is defined as the Oak Farms Dairy facility located at 3417 Leeland Street, Houston, Texas.
Oak Farms Dairy produces fluid milk products and is equipped with a refrigeration system containing anhydrous ammonia, C.A.S. #7664-41-7. Ammonia is the only regulated substance used at this facility. The refrigeration system contains approximately 30,000 pounds of ammonia which exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION
Releases are prevented by a combination of engineering and administrative controls. Engineering controls include automated system shutdown when safe parameters are exceeded. Administrative controls involve manual isolation and shutdown procedures to be performed by trained personnel. The system is also equipped with pressure relief valves that operate to prevent damage to system components should pressures reach unsafe levels. Operation of pressure relief valves will result in a controlled release of refrigerant.

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE SCENARIOS
Computer air models were developed based on a worst case release scenario involving the catastrophic structural failure of the system receiver. The receiver can potentially contain the largest quantity of ammonia in a single vessel at this facility. The model was produced using OCA guidance, including RMPComp.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility has developed a prevention program which complies with the requirements of OSHA CFR 29, 1910.119 Process Safety Management. This program includes procedures, training, and proactive maintenance measures to keep the system operating without catastrophic release.

EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN
The Emergency Action Plan for this facility calls for the immediate evacuation or shelter in place as determined necessary for the particular event. A third party response contractor is notified of an uncontrolled release event. The local fire department has been included in the no

tification and action plan. Oak Farms Dairy personnel are trained to assist the responders with information only, and would not participate in actual response.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases or reportable incidents at this facility in the last 5 years.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Planned changes to improve safety include the ongoing inspection and testing program, and regular replacement of deteriorated system components.  In all cases, improved process technology is employed where feasible.  Employees levels of awareness is enhanced by regular training programs and exercises.
